subject: US MARKET WRAP: Strong data, strong Dollar, equities mixed, USTs down
content:
• SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed; USD up; GBP down; EUR down; Crude up; Treasuries up
  • REAR VIEW: US data beats; Eurozone inflation revision
  • AHEAD: Russian Elections; UK CPI; Eurozone consumer confidence

 

* EQUITIES: SPX 0.2% at 2751.84, DJI +0.3% at 24946.57, NDX -0.2% at 7019.95

* SECTORS: CONS DISC (XLY): -0.1%, CONS STAP (XLP): 0.0%, ENERGY (XLE): +1.0%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +0.2%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.1%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +0.5%, MATERIALS (XLB): +0.1%, TECH (XLK): -0.1%, TELECOMS (XTL): +0.2%, UTILITIES (XLU): +1.0%

* Equity indices traded mixed with the NASDAQ underperforming, weighed on by Broadcom after earnings on Thursday after market. The energy sector outperformed after crude futures settled higher by almost 2%.

* USD strengthened after strong industrial production data, which jumped 1.1% (expected 0.3%), the strongest gain since October. The USD caught a second wind after the University of Michigan sentiment which rose to its highest level in 14 years. Reports of a hawkish thinktank report on the Fed also helped the USD push higher as it was said to suggest that the Fed will prepare markets for four rate hikes in 2018.

* EUR,  GBP Eurozone inflation was revised lower to 1.1% from 1.2% but this saw no major moves in the market with the EUR maintaining a weakening trend throughout the day as markets continue to digest the recent dovish message from the ECB. Similar price action was observed in GBP/USD ahead of a big week ahead including BoE decision, inflation & labour market data and the EU summit.

* CAD, AUD, NZD Commodity currencies were hit again as markets expect the economies could be worst hit from an escalation in trade wars. AUD/USD slipped to a 10 day low after breaking below the 200DMA at 0.7804.

* JPY trended higher in the European morning as USD/JPY broke back below 106.00. Strong US data lent support to the pair which reclaimed the 106.00 handle and then hovered around that level in the US afternoon.

* Treasuries : 10 YEAR T-NOTE FUTURES (JUNE 2018) SETTLES DOWN 5 TICKS AT 120.11 Yields were higher across the curve after the relatively strong data saw a sell-off in bonds in relatively good volume. However, volume and flows dried out at the end of the day and Treasuries meandered into the close.

* Crude: An early afternoon spike saw WTI and Brent crude futures jump to session highs amid no apparent fundamental catalyst. Some speculated that the move was based on details in the Michigan sentiment report which suggested strong expected demand during upcoming driving season. Others were pinning the jump on short-covering ahead of a weekend interview with the Saudi Crown Prince on 60 Minutes.

subject: NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) – US President Trump’s blocking of Qualcomm (QCOM) / Broadcom (AVGO) deal is unlikely to have an impact on NXP's deal with Qualcomm
Atlanta Fed GDPNow Q1 1.8% (Prev. 1.9%)
Weekly FX Wrap: more trade/tariff tiffs and political jitters, plus contrasting CB impulses and data
content: An almost clean sweep of stronger than expected US data and reports of a hawkish think tank report suggesting the Fed may prepare markets for 4 hikes this year next week (vs current dot plot consensus of 3), has boosted the Usd across the board and helped the DXY stage a firmer bounce above 90.000. However, the Dollar is still struggling vs the Jpy above 106.00 amidst ongoing land sale/cronyism claims against Japanese PM Abe and MoF chief Aso with the latter not attending next week’s G20 gathering as a result. The Greenback continues to be hampered by global protectionism factors and concerns about President Trump’s changing of the White House guard, but significantly less so than its NAFTA counterparts and namesakes down under in the commodity bloc. Indeed, Usd/Cad hit new 2018 highs and peaks above the 1.3000 level, with the Loonie also undermined by disappointing Canadian macro releases and a still cautious BoC. On that note, Governor Poloz sees slack in the economy that may allow more growth without stoking inflation. Usd/Cad stopped just short of 1.3100 on Friday and the big figure is the obvious next upside target before chart resistance around 1.3110. A raft of dovish ECB guidance due to sub-target inflation that was underscored by downside tweaks to final CPI data knocked the Eur, with the single currency losing grip of 1.2300 vs the Usd and breaching supports at the 1.2279 21 DMA, plus 1.2266 Fib vs 1.2412 at one stage. Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd recoiled even further and faster from best levels to circa 0.7720 and 0.7200 respectively vs 0.7916 and 0.7354 on a combination of global trade war fears and data misses (NZ Q4 GDP for example ahead of the RBNZ policy meeting next week). The Chf never really saw strong demand during risk-off trade/flows, and certainly after the SNB maintained that the Franc is highly valued – back down towards 0.9550 vs the Usd and near 1.1700 vs the Eur. Conversely, the Nok rallied sharply as the Norges Bank brought forward its rate hike guidance to August or September this year, and could have even mulled tightening sooner according to comments from a Deputy Governor. Eur/Nok broke down through a key technical level at 9.5300, then decent bids at 9.5000 and hit a 9.4745 approximate base before consolidating. Back to G10s, Gbp has been a relative outperformer with Cable mostly firmer within a 1.3900-1.4000 range and Eur/Gbp easing between 0.8850-00, largely due to rising hopes of a Brexit transition deal at next week’s EU Summit, but with the Irish border stand-off still a major if not the sticking point. Looking ahead, more major CB policy meetings, with the FOMC headlining.

BAML FX/Rates Sentiment Survey: Most investors anticipate increasing trade tensions, with lower equities and lower USD their preferred plays
content:
OTHER HIGHLIGHTS:

  • US: Despite expecting monetary policy divergence to drive USD, positioning remains short and sentiment is bearish, BAML says.
  • UK: UK expectations are downbeat, over half of participants believe there is a more than one-in-five chance of another UK election by the end of 2018. Over half see less than 40% chance of a transition deal being struck by next week's EU Council Summit meeting.
  • EZ: Only 6% believe the ECB will keep forward guidance unchanged after the end of net asset purchases. The majority see a significant strengthening in the guidance.
  • JAPAN: Investors are confident that the BoJ's stance will not change until 2019.

subject: DAILY US EQUITY OPENING NEWS - Qualcomm (QCOM) – A former chairman is reportedly looking for partners to help with a bid for the chipmaker
content:
16th March 2018

EARNINGS

  • Adobe (ADBE) - Q1 Adj. EPS USD 1.55 vs Exp. USD 1.44, revenue USD 2.08bln vs Exp. USD 2.05bln. Sees Q2 EPS at roughly USD 1.53 vs Exp. USD 1.44 and sees revenue roughly USD 2.15bln vs Exp. USD 2.05bln. (Newswires)
  • Broadcom (AVGO) - Q1 EPS USD 5.12 vs Exp. USD 5.04, revenue USD 5.33bln, vs Exp. USD 5.32bln. Sees Q2 revenue USD 5bln give or take USD75mln, vs Exp. USD 5bln. (Newswires)
  • Jabil (JBL) – Q2 core EPS USD 0.66 vs Exp. USD 0.62, revenue USD 5.3bln vs Exp. USD 4.9bln. (Newswires)
  • Overstock (OSTK) – Q4 Loss per share USD 3.72, may not compare to expected loss of USD 0.03, revenue USD 456.3mln vs Exp. USD 526.18mln. (Newswires)
  • Tiffany & Co (TIF) Q4 EPS USD 1.67 vs. Exp. USD 1.64, revenue USD 1.33bln vs. Exp. USD 1.31bln. SSS +3%. (Newswires)
  • Ulta Beauty (ULTA) – Q4 Adj. EPS USD 2.75 vs. Exp. USD 2.78, revenue USD 1.94 vs. Exp. USD 1.94bln. Approves a new share repurchase programme of USD 625mln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – Barclays lowered its price target for the co. to USD 168. (Newswires)
  • Intel (INTC) – The chipmaker told CNBC that its focus remains on Altera and Mobileye, not on Broadcom (AVGO). In line with Intel’s recent response regarding the reports that Intel was looking to acquire Broadcom. (CNBC)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The. pharmaceutical giant has received a binding offer worth roughly USD 2.1bln for its Lifescan business from Platinum Equity. (Newswires)
  • Nike (NKE) – Trevor Edwards, President of the co. has resigned as the co. received reports of workplace complaints. (Newswires)
  • United Technologies (UTX) – The co. has said that commodities are a headwind and that backlogs are a concern in the Middle East and China. (Newswires)
  • Wal-Mart (WMT) – The retail giant responded to accusations from a former executive saying an investigation found no evidence that the company was issuing misleading e-commerce results. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • ADT Inc (ADT) – Deutsche Bank note yesterdays pullback is a buying opportunity. (Deutsche Bank)
  • CVS Health (CVS) / Aetna (AET) – Republican Senator Cassidy says the DoJ should look into healthcare mergers and deals. Further for CVS, it is offering new shingle vaccines at more than 9800 pharmacies nationwide. (Newswires)
  • Equifax (EFX) – An Australian competition regulator said it is suing the co., alleging consumer law breaches by its Australian unit. (Newswires)
  • Kroger (KR) – The retailer announced the approval of a USD 1bln share repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) – The defence name has been awarded a USD 3.53bln government contract with the US army. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retail giant is planning a pickup service for its Whole Foods and a “marquee” of other retailers. (Newswires)
  • Broadcom (AVGO) – The chipmaker said it is likely to pursue smaller acquisitions of chipmakers after its failed takeover attempt of Qualcomm (QCOM). It also said its smart phone chip business would see demand fall in North America but would see it rise in South Korea. (Newswires)
  • JD.com (JD) – The co.’s finance unit is aiming to raise USD 1.9bln in fresh equity that could see its value double from previous year to over USD 20bln, according to sources. (Newswires)
  • Micron (MU) - JP Morgan say to stay long in the co. ahead of earnings next week. Separately, a Chinese article saying higher DRAM prices and shortage may last for all of 2018. (JP Morgan / China Times)
  • Netflix (NFLX) – RBC positive on the video streaming co., saying by 2022 it believes it can reach a global subscription base of 220mln – 250mln. (Prior estimate of 215mln). The analyst at RBC said this generates a 2022 EPS between USD 14 and USD 22, putting the stock on track to USD 660/shr. (RBC)
  • Qualcomm (QCOM) – A former chairman is reportedly looking for partners to help with a bid for the chipmaker. (FT)
  • Wynn Resorts (WYNN) – The former CEO, Steve Wynn, may sell all or some of his stake in the co, he owns 11.8% of the name, and his wife owns 9.3% stake. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Alibaba (BABA) – WSJ’s heard on the street column reporting the Chinese retail giant’s plan to list on Chinese stock exchange may not be much benefit to shareholders. (Newswires)
  • FireEye (FEYE) – The co. remains on watch after reports that both Cisco (CSCO) and Symantec (SYMC) were interested in a possible acquisition of the co. (CNBC)
  • Magellan Midstream (MMP) – The co. does not expect a material impact after the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission revised its policy statement by eliminating income tax allowances cost recovery in rates. (Newswires)
  • Meredith (MDP) / Time (TIME) – Meredith is looking to explore a sale of its Time, Fortune, Money and Sports illustrated assets following its USD 1.84bln takeover of time. (Newswires)
  • Steel Dynamics (STLD) – The co. forecasts Q1 EPS between USD 0.88 and USD 0.92, vs Exp. USD 0.94. (Newswires)

subject: Fixed Income: another downtown in EU debt
content: Bunds and Gilts have bother retreated further from earlier Eurex and Liffe highs (although for the former not as early as normal of course given the technical problems), with the 10 year German bond dipping marginally below par at 158.09 (-5 ticks) and its UK equivalent to 121.85 (also -4 ticks), with reports of more spread activity, but this time Gilts being sold vs US Treasuries by real money accounts. According to a major bank this inter-market trade has been implemented in ‘good size’.

subject: UBS says its bullish EURUSD
content:
- UBS says its term-premia analysis suggests US curve flattening has further potential, which is consistent with USD weakness.
- Bank notes that in the EZ, dynamics are opposite, and term-premia remains substantially negative, with more room for unwind - particularly at the long-end - as ECB normalises policy.

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - Risk Aversion Driving G10 FX; CAD Vulnerable
content:
• USD mixed; JPY, gold, CHF leading as AUD, NZD & CAD underperform.
  • CAD weak and vulnerable as markets adjust BoC view in light of trade concerns.
  • EUR steadies below critical 1.2350 level; CPI revised slightly lower; neutral.
  • GBP consolidating recent gains with impressive moves on crosses this week.
  • JPY outperforming in context of elevated risk aversion; EURJPY nearing 130.
  • AUD softens on Debelle comments, entering NA session on the lows.
  • MXN extending decline through 50 day MA; vulnerable into NA open.

subject: EU DEBT LATEST: core bonds paring gains, while Eurozone periphery stays perky
content: Price action suggests and supports the notion that some spread positioning has been behind the pull-back in Bunds towards parity from +21 ticks at best, while Italian BTPs and Spanish Bonos retain a larger proportion of their gains. Gilts are also slipping back further from Liffe intraday highs and back below the 122.00 level and perhaps also seeing some loss of momentum on technical grounds as the early advance did not seriously trouble near term resistance at 122.24. Back to Eurex and the non-core outperformance, soft inflation data and more dovish ECB vibes are bullish factors, and perhaps looming ratings reviews from Moody’s and Fitch on Italy, plus S&P for Portugal are being eyed on the basis that the agencies could be positive.

subject: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The. Pharmaceutical giant has received a binding offer worth roughly USD 2.1bln for its Lifescan business from Platinum Equity
DAILY US OPENING NEWS: The final session of the week sees European bourses trading in mixed fashion following from the indecisive lead from its Asian and US counterparts
content:
• The final session of the week sees European bourses trading in mixed fashion following from the indecisive lead from its Asian and US counterparts
  • The Dollar remains mixed against major counterparts as US President Trump continues to rejig top level White House personnel
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US building permits, housing starts and U. of Michigan sentiment data

 

ASIA

Asia stocks traded mixed following a similar indecisive lead from Wall St. and as overnight trade lacked any tangible catalysts to dictate price action. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were mixed with Australia led by Consumer Staples as Wesfarmers shares surged on plans to spin off its Coles supermarket chain, while Nikkei 225 was kept subdued by a firmer JPY and as cover up allegations were fuelled by reports PM Abe knew of the document alterations days before the public admission. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.12) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.7) were choppy after the PBoC skipped open market operations and instead announced to lend CNY 327bln via its MLF, while US equity futures were briefly pressured on administration instability concerns after initial reports that National Security Adviser McMaster was said to be removed from position, although this was later denied by the White House. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with support seen amid losses in Japanese stocks and with the BoJ also present in the market with its Rinban amounts left unchanged, while Aussie yields declined across the curve following a 10yr auction in which the average yield was down nearly 20bps from prior.

Japanese PM Abe was reported to be aware of alterations made to documents in land sale days prior to the public admission. (Nikkei)

Japan’s upper and lower houses of parliament approved BoJ Governor Kuroda for a 2nd term, while they also approved Amamiya and Wakatabe as Deputy Governors. (Newswires)

PBoC refrained from open market operations, but then announced to lend CNY 327bln via 1-year Medium-term Lending Facility with the rate unchanged at 3.25%. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3340 (Prev. 6.3141)

Japanese government have upgraded its view on inflation and sees inflation rising moderately, from previously seeing inflation flat. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB’s Praet (Dove) said Eurozone economy may have more slack than thought, possibly slowing inflation rebound, but he does see an improvement in the path of inflation. He added that the ECB must be more precise on short term rates once bond buying ends; rate guidance will need to be specified. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

There were initial reports on Twitter citing Washington Post that National Security Adviser McMaster is said to be removed from position, although this was later denied by the White House. (Newswires)

An EU Official said they are still hoping for a Brexit deal by October, further stating that the Brexit transition will not be valid if there is no Irish border deal (Newswires)

EU Inflation, Final YY (Feb) 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%)

EU Core Inflation Final YY (Feb) 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.0%)

EQUITIES

The final session of the week, sees European bourses trading in mixed fashion following from the indecisive lead from its Asian and US counterparts. On a sector basis, energy names are outperforming this morning amid the slight push higher in oil prices. UK homebuilders are lagging in the FTSE 100, after Berkeley Group warned over challengers in increasing housing supply further. Elsewhere, NEX Group (+32%) shares surge the most in history after they confirmed that CME Group have approached them.

FX

Not a lot of change in Usd/G10 and other currency pairings as the same themes continue to impact sentiment and moves. The Dollar remains rather mixed against major counterparts as US President Trump continues to rejig top level White House personnel, while pursuing his policies on the trade and tax front. Usd/Jpy is probing a bit deeper below the 106.00 level amidst reports suggesting PM Abe may have been aware of tampered documents before the whole land sale scandal was publicly aired. The headline pair has been down to 105.65, just ahead of bids around 105.50 and of course recent lows circa 105.25. Eur/Usd remains capped by benign ECB inflation talk and actual data (Eurozone headline CPI revised lower similarly with Italian CPI in the final February release) but holding above 1.2300 and could be contained by decent option expiry interest for Friday at the figure (2.6 bn) and 1.2350 (1.3 bn). Cable still looks firmer within a wide 1.3900-1.4000 range, with Eur/Gbp slipping further towards 0.8800 on hopes of a Brexit transition deal can be agreed, assuming the Irish border issue is resolved first. Usd/Cad consolidating just below new 2018 highs around 1.3070 amidst ongoing NAFTA concerns and following some weak Canadian data with manufacturing sales up next. Kiwi still the G10 laggard after the NZ GDP miss and a slowdown in the manufacturing PMI overnight, with Nzd/Usd now around 0.7250 and the Aud/Nzd cross rebounding from the low 1.0700 area, despite Aud/Usd losing the 0.7800 handle on the aforementioned heightened global protectionism risk.

FIXED INCOME

It’s been a slow grind, but nevertheless Bunds continue to climb and with more macro impetus this time via softer than expected inflation from Italy and the Eurozone as a whole. The new/latest Eurex session peak is 158.35 (+21 ticks in the day) and basically touching the base of the previously identified zone on the charts ahead of 158.68 resistance and upside levels that correspond to about 0.5% in yield terms. Meanwhile, Gilts are also probing further ahead and closer to the nearest bullish tech objective up at 122.24, at 122.12 (+23 ticks), and USTs are seeing more bull-flattening.

COMMODITIES

Commodities have seen a slight reprieve this morning with oil prices making marginal gains, however WTI fell short by around USD 0.10 off yesterday’s high of USD 61.55/bbl. In the metals complex, gold has pushed up by USD 4/oz, having found support at the earlier weeks low of USD 1313.70/oz

subject: Eni (ENI IM) sets dividend of EUR 0.83.share; says buyback remains an option to distribute excess cash vs. leverage target of 0.20-0.25
reaction_details: In an immediate reaction, company share price rose from EUR 13.8760 to intraday highs of EUR 13.9720

subject: US is demanding EU concessions on steel and defence policy, adding they want a permanent limit of EU steel exports to the US
EU Official states that Brexit transition will not be valid if there is no Irish border deal
EU Official says they are still hoping for a Brexit deal by October
Tiffany & Co (TIF) Q4 EPS USD 1.67 vs. Exp. USD 1.64, revenue USD 1.33bln vs. Exp. USD 1.31bln
content: • Quarterly comparable store sales rose by 3%

subject: BAML Weekly Flow Report: Record USD 43.3bln week of equity inflows; stocks vulnerable to creaking credit, lower yields, higher LIBOR, higher USD
content:
SUMMARY:
- Equities: record $43.3bn (record $43.9bn ETF inflows, $0.6bn mutual fund outflows)
- Bonds: small inflows ($2.4bn)
- Precious metals: small inflows ($0.2bn)

ASSET CLASS FLOWS:
- Equities: record $43.3bn (record $43.9bn ETF inflows, $0.6bn mutual fund outflows)
- Bonds: small inflows ($2.4bn)
- Precious metals: small inflows ($0.2bn)

FIXED INCOME FLOWS:
- IG bond fund inflows 63 of past 64 weeks ($1.3bn)
- HY bond outflows for 9 weeks, longest streak since 2007 ($0.9bn)
- Small EM debt outflows ($0.7bn)
- Small muni fund inflows ($0.2bn)
- Govt/Tsy inflows for past 8 weeks, first time since Feb'16 ($0.3bn)
- TIPS inflows 20 of past 21 weeks ($1.0bn)
- Largest bank loan fund inflows in 46 weeks ($0.8bn)

EQUITY FLOWS:
- US: record inflows ($34.6bn)
- Japan: inflows for 15 straight weeks, first time since 2013 ($2.9bn)
- Europe: modest outflows ($1.3bn)
- EM: modest inflows ($2.7bn)
- By style: 4th highest inflows into US large cap ($22.0bn), record into US growth ($5.8bn), US small cap ($5.4bn), US value ($4.1bn)
- By sector: inflows into tech ($2.6bn, record), financials ($1.6bn), materials ($0.3bn), healthcare ($0.1bn), consumer ($0.03bn); outflows real estate ($0.03bn), energy ($0.3bn), utilities ($0.2bn)

Elsewhere, NEX Group (+35%) shares surge the most in history after they confirmed that CME Group have approached them.

subject: BoE says Brexit risk do not warrant additional capital buffer for UK banks
content:
• Sees rising domestic risk appetite in mortgage market with high loan-to-income ratios
  • UK current account continues to be funded by capital inflows, increasing UK reliance on foreign investors
  • Central bank also warns of material risks from Brexit

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE HAS NOW FINISHED, PLEASE REVERT BACK TO YOUR ORIGINAL CHANNEL FOR COVERAGE ON THE UK & EUROPEAN SESSION
Lanxess (LXS GY) no longer in consortium bidding for Akzo Nobel (AKZA NA) specialty chemicals business
reaction_details: An immediate reaction seen with a downtick in Akzo Nobel (AKZA NA) shares from EUR 80.400 to EUR 80.160

subject: Russian Central Bank Monetary Policy Chief says his department will advise to cut key interest rates on 23rd March
Czech Central Banker Dedek says may need to hike rates quicker due to state of the economy
Bunds: back with a bullish bias, albeit belatedly
content: Eurex is finally open for business after the technical issues that prevented the exchange from starting at the normal time, but buyers appear to have been champing at the bit given the price action seen so far. Indeed, the 10 year German bond was marked up 10 ticks initially and after a brief wobble has probed a bit further to the upside between 158.29-20 vs yesterday’s 158.14 close. So, Thursday’s intraday peak has been surpassed and charts via market contacts flag 158.36-39 and the next bullish area before 158.68 and beyond, which also aligns with 0.5% in the benchmark cash yield. Gilts have now inched up to 122.04, 15 ticks above the previous Liffe settlement.

subject: FX option expiries for today's 10am NY cut (1400GMT)
Japanese government have upgraded its view on inflation and sees inflation rising moderately, from previously seeing inflation flat
Gilts testing 122.00 level again, Eurex still experiencing tech issues
content: UK debt doing pretty well while left to their own devices as it were, with an early Liffe approach on recent 122.00+ peaks within a 121.92-122.02 range vs Thursday’s 121.89 close and absent of anything major on the fundamental front tech-based traders and spec accounts may attempt to push the 10 year Gilt future up towards 122.24. Back to Eurex, and it remains uncertain when Friday’s session will begin, with several times touted from 8.30GMT onwards.

subject: ECB says banks borrowed EUR 107mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 626.16bln
EU morning movers: NEX (NXG LM) +30.0%, Altice (ATC NA) +3.5%, Rubis (RUI FP) +3.5%, Telecom Italia (TIT IM) +1.2%, Elior (ELIOR FP) -1.4%, Berkeley Group (BKG LN) -5.6%
Norges Bank Deputy Chief says uncertainty remains and it would not have been right to raise rates now
analysis_details:
• Yesterday's Norges Bank rate decision saw a hawkish upgrade to the rate trajectory, the central bank stating the likeliness of seeing tightening after summer 2018 compared to previous autumn 2018.
  • Governor Olsen then said it's hard to tell whether the rate hike would come in August or September and added he does not expect two rate hikes in 2018.

subject: Short Sterling strip flat overall, as anticipated
content: Not much to glean from peer STIR futures, so 3 month UK futures are just a tick either side of unchanged off the Liffe open and there is little on Friday’s domestic agenda to offer independent direction, as the latest FPC is unlikely to provide much in the way of market-moving headlines. However, Brexit developments will continue to be monitored and there is a full US data docket to digest ahead of next week’s FOMC. External leads for Gilts also look uninspiring with US Treasury futures flat aside from the long bond amidst yet more curve flattening. Note also, technical problems still delaying trade on the Eurex exchange and could last for some time beyond the earlier anticipated 7.50GMT open.

subject: Russian Ambassador says Russia will exert maximum pressure on Britain
Eurex update - expected opening time 7.50GMT
Eurex experiencing technical problems, trading delayed as a result
ECB’s Praet says Eurozone economy may have more slack than thought, possibly slowing inflation rebound, but he does see an improvement in the path of inflation.
content: • He adds that ECB must be more precise on short term rates once bond buying ends; rate guidance will need to be specified

subject: Additional European equities stories post-the release of the Daily EU Equity Opening News
content:
Elior Group (ELIOR FP) – Esther Gaide to replace Olivier Dubois as CFO. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – CEO says in the annual report remains committed to objective of delivering net profit and a competitive dividend pay-out for 2018. Co. expects 2018 revenues to be higher than 2017. Co. will propose a dividend of EUR 0.11/shr. (Newswires)

Ladbrokes (LCL LN) and William Hill (WMH LN) – The FCA said the two bookmakers have created a ‘false market’ in their shares by providing ‘misleading information’ about how their operation would be affected if new limits on fixed-odds terminals were imposed. In October, a government review into the industry reported that machines should have their maximum stakes slashed to between GBP 50.00 and GBP 2.00 rather than allowing to place bets up to GBP 100 every 20 seconds. (FT)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM)/ Vivendi (VIV FP)- Elliott Advisors believes Telecom Italia needs a truly independent board to improve governance and performance and add “poor stewardship” under Vivendi-controlled board has resulted in “deeply troubling corporate governance issues” at Telecom Italia. Elliott now holds in excess of 3% of Telecom Italia’s ordinary shares. Elliott also believes that separate listing or partial sale of Telecom Italia’s network company would maximise its value. (Newswires)

Deutsche Post (DPW GY) – Co. said it’s launching a delivery service for online retailers in eight US cities, taking a swipe at key players UPS (UPS) and FedEx (FDX). (Newswires)

National Grid (NG/ LN) – The three-year rate plan of Niagara Mohawk Electric & Gas was confirmed, with new rates to be finally approved on 1st April and a capex of USD 2.5bln. (Newswires)

Altice (ATC NA) - Consolidated 2017 revenue EUR 23.43bln vs. Exp. EUR 23.53bln. 2017 EBITDA EUR 9.39bln vs. Exp. EUR 9.36bln. Co. hopes to sign deal on sale of Telecoms Towers assets in Q2. Assets have attracted interest from more than 10 parties. (Newswires)

Berkley group (BKG LN) – Co. cannot increase building volumes due to planning constraints. (Newswires)

NEX GROUP (NXG LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SOCGEN

DASSAULT AVIATION (AM FP) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SOCGEN

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from GKN, Shell, Linde, Siemens and Bayer
content:
16th March 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia stocks traded mixed following a similar indecisive lead from Wall St. and as overnight trade lacked any tangible catalysts to dictate price action. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were mixed with Australia led by Consumer Staples as Wesfarmers shares surged on plans to spin off its Coles supermarket chain, while Nikkei 225 was kept subdued by a firmer JPY and as cover up allegations were fuelled by reports PM Abe knew of the document alterations days before the public admission. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were choppy after the PBoC skipped open market operations and instead announced to lend CNY 327bln via its MLF, while US equity futures were briefly pressured on administration instability concerns after initial reports that National Security Adviser McMaster was said to be removed from position, although this was later denied by the White House.

FTSE

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. is said to be selling its upstream assets in New Zealand to Austria’s OMV (OMV AV) for a deal of USD 578mln, as reported on Thursday. Separately, ENI (ENI IM) and the co. were accused by Amnesty International of negligence when addressing spills in Nigeria (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

NEX Group (NXG LN) - CME Group (CME) is reportedly considering a bid for the Co., Nex confirmed to have received a first approach from its competitor CME, for a multibillion-pound deal. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Linde (LIN GY) – Co. said the EU Commission has suspended its review of the Co.’s merger with Praxair (PX) while it awaits requested information, but it expects the suspension to be lifted next week. (Newswires)

Siemens (SIE GY) – Co. Healthineers IPO placement price was set at EUR 28/share. (Newswires)

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Co. issued a recall of Alka-Seltzer Plus products due to a labelling error. (Newswires)

Fraport (FRA GY) – 2017 revenue +13.5% to EUR 2.9348bln. 2017 EBITDA down 4.8% to EUR 1.0032bln . Proposed dividend EUR 1.50/shr. Sees dividend for 2018 higher in comparison to previous year. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Societe Generale (GLE FP) – The bank is negotiating a financial settlement with authorities and believes it has adequate provisions. Co. sees an increase in net financial debt to as much as EUR 4bln in 2018. (Newswires)

Carrefour (CA FP) – Co. said it was buying a majority stake in a French company that delivers meal kits – Quitoque, as part of plans to beef up its digital offering(Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Rubis (RUI FP) – FY Net income EUR 266mln vs Exp. EUR 208mln, EBITDA EUR 496mln vs Exp. EUR 500mln. (Newswires)   

BROKER MOVES

PAN-EUROPE

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) – The legal fight over a complex financial instrument betting on stock market swings is expanding, with a new lawsuit targeting one of the product’s service provider. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Pargesa (PARG SW) – Co. reports FY2017 net profit of CHF 382mln (Prev. loss of CHF 32mln). (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

Equities traded mixed with no fundamental catalyst to be found by midday trading. A slight downtick was observed on the news that Special Counsel Mueller had subpoenaed the Trump organisation seeking Russia documents, which dented risk sentiment. Reports that Walmart had issued misleading e-commerce results gave further impetus to the downtick.

SPX -0.08% at 2747, DJI +0.45% at 24873, NDX -0.14% at 7030

SECTORS: CONS DISC (XLY): -0.07%, CONS STAP (XLP): -0.64%, ENERGY (XLE): -0.42%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +0.09%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -0.14%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +0.33%, MATERIALS (XLB): -1.28%, TECH (XLK): +0.08%, TELECOMS (XTL): -0.22%, UTILITIES (XLU): -0.05%

Adobe Systems Inc (ADBE) - Q4 EPS USD 1.55 vs. Exp. USD 1.44, revenue USD 2.08bln vs. Exp. USD 2.05bln. (Newswires)

Broadcom Ltd (AVGO) - Q4 EPS USD 5.12 vs. Exp. USD 5.04, revenue USD 5.33bln vs. Exp. USD 5.32bln. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Mixed trade in Asia with very little in the way of tangible catalysts to dictate price action
content:
16th March 2018

  • Mixed trade in Asia with very little in the way of tangible catalysts to dictate price action.
  • US equity futures took a slight dip on reports that National Security Adviser McMaster had been removed from position, however was later denied by the White House.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Eurozone Inflation, US building permits, housing starts and U. of Michigan sentiment data.

ASIA

Asia stocks traded mixed following a similar indecisive lead from Wall St. and as overnight trade lacked any tangible catalysts to dictate price action. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were mixed with Australia led by Consumer Staples as Wesfarmers shares surged on plans to spin off its Coles supermarket chain, while Nikkei 225 was kept subdued by a firmer JPY and as cover up allegations were fuelled by reports PM Abe knew of the document alterations days before the public admission. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were choppy after the PBoC skipped open market operations and instead announced to lend CNY 327bln via its MLF, while US equity futures were briefly pressured on administration instability concerns after initial reports that National Security Adviser McMaster was said to be removed from position, although this was later denied by the White House. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with support seen amid losses in Japanese stocks and with the BoJ also present in the market with its Rinban amounts left unchanged, while Aussie yields declined across the curve following a 10yr auction in which the average yield was down nearly 20bps from prior.

Japanese PM Abe was reported to be aware of alterations made to documents in land sale days prior to the public admission. (Nikkei)

Japan’s upper and lower houses of parliament approved BoJ Governor Kuroda for a 2nd term, while they also approved Amamiya and Wakatabe as Deputy Governors. (Newswires)

PBoC refrained from open market operations, but then announced to lend CNY 327bln via 1-year Medium-term Lending Facility with the rate unchanged at 3.25%. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3340 (Prev. 6.3141)
 

UK/EU

Irish border dispute is said to be complicating Brexit transition talks, while it was also reported that UK and EU officials have agreed to take part in "intensive" talks to resolve the issue of the Irish border. (Newswires)

FX

FX markets were mostly quiet overnight amid a lack of drivers and sparse data releases. As such, the greenback held on to most of the prior day’s gains with the DXY maintaining above the 90.00 level, although the quiet tone somewhat provided much-needed respite for major currencies after the recent selling against USD. JPY remained firm as the cronyism scandal threatens to cloud over Abenomics, and with flows into the safe-haven also spurred amid the false McMasters firing report. Elsewhere, a subdued commodity-complex has in turn kept related currencies pressured, with NZD the worst performer in an extension of the post-GDP slide and amid a rebound in AUD/NZD from prior support around 1.0705-1.0710.


COMMODITIES

Trade in commodities left much to be desired with WTI crude little changed to cling on to the recently reclaimed USD 61/bbl level. Prices across the metals complex were also flat with gold near US sessions lows as the greenback retained most of its recent gains, while copper was lacklustre alongside the lacklustre risk tone seen in the region. 

GEOPOLITICAL

South Korea and US reportedly plan to announce their military exercise plans next week. (Newswires)
 

US

Bear flattening was observed with the short-end underperforming in the curve. A bid was later observed after the Mueller subpoena news hit the wires, but overall volumes were relatively light and liquidity thin which IFR noted could be the trend leading up to the Fed rate decision on Wednesday. 10yr T-note futures (June 2018) settled down 1.5 ticks at 120.60.

US Special Counsel Mueller has subpoenaed the Trump Organization demanding documents on Russia. Furthermore, there were also source reports that the Trump Organization has been producing documents to Mueller and Congressional investigations for months, while the White House also said it will continue to cooperate with Special Counsel Mueller but would not comment on Trump Organisation subpoenas. (Newswires)

There were initial reports on Twitter citing Washington Post that National Security Adviser McMaster is said to be removed from position, although this was later denied by the White House. (Newswires)

subject: Russia Deputy Foreign Minister says will use principle of parity in response to US sanctions and does not rule further measures
EU's Moscovici says we will give a firm response to US tariffs
Nikkei 225 close down 0.6% at 21,676
ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded indecisive amid lack of drivers
content: Asia stocks traded mixed following a similar indecisive lead from Wall St. and as overnight trade lacked any tangible catalysts to dictate price action. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were mixed with Australia led by Consumer Staples as Wesfarmers shares surged on plans to spin off its Coles supermarket chain, while Nikkei 225 was kept subdued by a firmer JPY and as cover up allegations were fuelled by reports PM Abe knew of the document alterations days before the public admission. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were choppy after the PBoC skipped open market operations and instead announced to lend CNY 327bln via its MLF, while US equity futures were briefly pressured on administration instability concerns after initial reports that National Security Adviser McMaster was said to be removed from position, although this was later denied by the White House. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with support seen amid losses in Japanese stocks and with the BoJ also present in the market with its Rinban amounts left unchanged, while Aussie yields declined across the curve following a 10yr auction in which the average yield was down nearly 20bps from prior.

content:
HDFC Bank (HDFCB IS)
- Co. raised INR 23bln through bond issuance. (Moneycontrol)

Tata Motors (TTMT IS)

Gold-related

Financials
- India government responded to RBI Governor Patel’s calls for reforms to give the RBI more authority over public sector banks in which the government said that the RBI already had enough powers to act against errant lenders. (Times of India)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia indecisive amid lack of drivers and false-firing reports
content:
Asia stocks trade indecisive following a similar mixed lead from Wall St and with overnight trade lacking any significant catalysts to dictate price action. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) are mixed with Australia led by Consumer Staples as Wesfarmers shares surge on plans to spin off its Coles supermarket chain, while Nikkei 225 is kept subdued by a firmer JPY and with claims of a cover up being fuelled by reports PM Abe knew of the document alterations days ahead of the public admission. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) are mixed after the PBoC skipped open market operations but instead announced to lend CNY 327bln via MLF, and US equity futures were briefly pressured on concerns of US administration instability after initial reports that National Security Adviser McMaster was said to be removed from position, although this was later denied by the White House.

FX markets are quiet overnight amid a lack of tangible drivers and sparse data releases. As such, the greenback has held on to most of the prior day’s gains with the DXY maintaining above the 90.00 level, although the quiet tone has somewhat provided much-needed respite for major currencies after the recent selling against USD. Elsewhere, JPY continues to firm as the cronyism scandal threatens to cloud over Abenomics and with safe-haven flows also exacerbated amid the false McMasters firing report, while a subdued commodity-complex has in turn kept related currencies pressured.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are marginally higher with support seen amid losses in Japanese stocks and as the BoJ kept the amounts of today’s Rinban operation unchanged, while Aussie yields declined across the curve following a 10yr auction in which the average yield was down nearly 20bps from prior.

content:

PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE STOCK NEWS: Pegatron (4938 TT) FY net missed expectations, as Q4 net declined 40% Y/Y
content:
TAIWAN

Cathay Financial Holding (2882 TT)
- Co. said its net value rose by TWD 35.8bln after reclassification of its financial assets under IFRS 9 standards. (Taipei Times)

ChipMOS Technologies (8150 TT)
- Co. Q4 net fell 73% Y/Y to TWD 163mln. (Taipei Times)

Pegatron (4938 TT)
- Co. FY17 net TWD 14.7bln vs. Exp. TWD 16.7bln, while Q4 net fell 40% Y/Y to TWD 3.7bln. (Newswires)

Other News
- Taiwan is said to consider measures in reaction to China’s policy of offering incentives to attract investment and talent from Taiwan. (Focus Taiwan)

 

SINGAPORE

Chip Eng Seng Corporation (CHIP SP)
- Co. is exiting the Tower Melbourne project after it found a buyer for the site. (Straits Times)

City Developments (CIT SP)
- Co.  is to release units next week for The Tapestry condominium. (Straits Times)

Property
- New private home sales in February declined 61.5% Y/Y to 377 units which was attributed to the Chinese New Year holidays. (Straits Times)
